answers.answer: I'm so sorry you're experiencing this.  Ultimately you'll want to seek a physician's diagnosis, but here's a few causes that can lead to mulitple chemical pregnancies:Endocrine (Hormonal) Imbalances resulting in a short luteal phase.  A luteal phase must be long enough, at least 10 days (over 12 days being ideal), to allow a fertilized egg to have a chance to implant and mature.  If the luteal phase is too short, you'll begin to shed the lining (period) because your body hasn't enough time to register there's a fertilized egg.  Most physicians will prescribe Clomid to promote optimal ovulation and a health progesterone level in the luteal phase.Uterine Abnormalties are also common, such as a heart-shaped uterus, or a uterus that may have cysts, fibroids, scar tissue development, or endometriosis, all of which impede successful implantation.Production of Antibodies by your immune system is also known to cause miscarriages.  This is when the mother's own body rejects or fights off this new growth (fetus) by producing antibodies.  A blood test would be able to determine if the antibodies are being produced close to the time of a miscarriage.Uncontrolled diabetes, overweight/underweight, thyroid disease, high blood pressure, unknown infections, or other medical disorders can have an effect, too.If you check out okay in all these categories and tests performed by your physician, you may want to have your partner's sperm tested for prostaglandins, a treatable condition.  Good luck!!

question: I had two pregnancy loses in the 4th week, what could be the reasons?
title: Early pregnancy lose
